briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon, everyone. We will now begin the climate change expert spokesperson briefing for February 23, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis and Complex Threats
sections.content: Threats from climate change are intensifying worldwide, including on the Korean Peninsula. This month alone, 85 wildfires occurred on the Korean Peninsula [4], and research has also been released indicating a threefold increase in wildfire risk globally [59, 77]. Winter storms in California, USA, were insufficient to alleviate climate change concerns [37], and the risk of avalanches is also increasing due to climate change [38, 62]. Furthermore, climate change is exacerbating inflation [42], acting as a complex threat alongside war in Sudan [48], and ultimately threatening human life in various ways, to the extent that the possibility of food riots has been raised [81]. In particular, former President Trump's calls for easing pollution regulations are clashing with the reality of climate change, which includes increased household costs and public health threats [53, 54], leading to louder warnings about the severity of the climate crisis [65, 70].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International and Domestic Trends through Climate Litigation and Policy Discussions
sections.content: Legal and policy discussions for addressing climate change are active. In the United States, the Supreme Court has agreed to hear attempts by oil and gas companies to block climate change lawsuits [34, 39, 41, 44, 45, 46, 49, 50, 51, 52, 55, 57, 58, 63, 67, 68, 69, 73, 74, 75, 76], marking a significant turning point for climate-related litigation [35]. Domestically, a climate litigation group met with the Speaker of the National Assembly to express concerns about deficiencies in the public discussion process for amending the Carbon Neutrality Act [6]. Speaker Woo Won-shik emphasized that carbon neutrality is a fundamental rights issue and stated that the voices of future generations would be reflected in legislation based on public consensus [8, 14]. These movements demonstrate that addressing climate change is being recognized not merely as an environmental issue, but as a matter of legal and social justice.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Expansion of Community-Centered Carbon Neutrality Education and Practices
sections.content: Various educational and promotional activities are actively underway in local communities, both domestically and internationally, to raise awareness of climate change and promote carbon neutrality practices. The Wonju Climate Change Promotion Center is hosting a special exhibition titled 'Renewable Energy in Everyday Life for Carbon Neutrality' [1, 5], and the Cheongju Land Climate Change Experience Center has reopened after remodeling, launching 'Participatory Carbon Neutrality Education' [2, 3]. In Jeju, 1,800 children are learning about carbon neutrality through activities such as planting 'billenaeng' [7], as children's carbon neutrality climate schools are being actively promoted [15]. Furthermore, efforts to raise awareness and foster dialogue on climate change are continuing across various sectors of society, including climate change quilting [56], expressions of commitment by Catholic faithful to halt climate change [64], and the important role of Black communities [66] [72, 78, 79].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Renewable Energy Transition and Green Industry Investment
sections.content: The transition to renewable energy and investment in green industries for achieving carbon neutrality are accelerating both domestically and internationally. Gwangmyeong City is developing a sustainable smart carbon-neutral city model [10, 11], while Yeongju City and Uljin County are operating a carbon point system that provides benefits to drivers practicing carbon neutrality, thereby encouraging citizen participation [12, 13, 18, 20, 21, 23]. Dobong-gu is pursuing a reduction of 157,014 tons of greenhouse gases this year [17], and an energy transition policy debate was held in Yongin City [16]. Internationally, China is accelerating carbon neutrality in maritime logistics by utilizing shipbuilding and battery technologies [9], and Chubu Electric Power of Japan has agreed to acquire a stake in an Indian renewable energy company [24], indicating an expanding trend in renewable energy investment [28]. M&A in the U.S. renewable energy sector is also regaining vitality [26], and a major structural overhaul of the power grid is underway to align with the 100 GW era of renewable energy [27, 29], signifying a large-scale transition. However, it has also become apparent that solar power expansion policies are facing issues such as discarded panels and grid instability, necessitating a policy course correction [31].

briefing.closing: In today's briefing, we have covered a range of news, from the severity of the climate crisis to global efforts to address it. As we face unprecedented climate threats, legal and policy responses, along with community-level actions and efforts to transition to renewable energy, are becoming increasingly crucial. This concludes today's climate briefing.
